qas.question: Who was featured in the most well-known part of Burke's Reflections?
Who said Burke wrote 'pure foppery' about Marie-Antoinette?
How did Marie-Antoinette react to Burke's writing about her?
What did Philip Francis call Marie-Antoinette?
When did Marie-Antoinette read Burke's writings?
How did Marie-Antoinette react to Edward Gibbon's praise?
Who thought the October Days were a cowardly attack on the Jacobins?

context: The most famous passage in Burke's Reflections was his description of the events of <b5_0>5–6 October 1789<b5_0/> and the part of <a0_0>Marie-Antoinette<a0_0/> in them. Burke's account differs little from modern historians who have used primary sources. His use of flowery language to describe it, however, provoked both praise and criticism. <a1_0>Philip Francis<a1_0/> wrote to Burke saying that what he wrote of Marie-Antoinette was "<b4_0>pure foppery<b4_0/>". <a2_0><b7_0>Edward Gibbon<b7_0/><a2_0/>, however, reacted differently: "I adore his chivalry". Burke was informed by an Englishman who had talked with the Duchesse de Biron, that when Marie-Antoinette was reading the passage, <a3_0><b6_0>she burst into tears<b6_0/><a3_0/> and took considerable time to finish reading it. Price had rejoiced that the French king had been "led in triumph" during the October Days, but to <b8_0>Burke<b8_0/> this symbolised the opposing revolutionary sentiment of the Jacobins and the natural sentiments of those who shared his own view with horror—that the ungallant assault on Marie-Antoinette—was a cowardly attack on a defenceless woman.
